intro: Hippochaete variegata subsp. alaskana, commonly known as the Alaska chia, is a member of the Pedaliaceae family. It is a herbaceous plant native to the coastal regions of Alaska and western Canada. The plant is characterized by its lance-shaped leaves and small, yellow flowers that bloom in the summer. It thrives in sandy, well-drained soils and is adapted to the cool, maritime climate of its native habitat. The seeds of this subspecies are edible and have been traditionally used by Indigenous peoples for food and medicinal purposes.
